newsitem.title: UK: Upside LME copper options targeted in covering move.
newsitem.headline: Upside LME copper options targeted in covering move.

text.p: A scramble to cover short copper option positions by a major Korean firm pushed up volatilities this week, while granting by the same company depressed aluminium vols to historic lows, traders said.

Nearby upside copper options were purchased as cover by a Korean metals company which had been prominent in the market at the end of last year and early 1997 for granting large lumps of copper and aluminium options, they added.
The firm has been running a short book and were caught out by the run-up in LME prices, which hit a fresh one-year peak of $2,530, basis three-months, on Thursday.
One options source said the buying of upside options was linked to an expanded credit line granted by a major U.S. investment bank.
The credit was approved on condition that $2,600 and $2,700 calls were bought as protection against further price rises, he said.
Another source said the Korean positions were taken over by the metals trading arm of a large investment bank.
On Wednesday, LME data showed turnover of 2,190 lots of $2,700 calls and on Thursday 1,460 lots in June $2,600 calls.
In addition, some producers have been buying downside fourth quarter puts, traders said. On Thursday, LME data shows turnover of 1,170 lots of $2,150 puts for October through December.
Implied volatility on the $2,600s and $2,700s traded as high as 24.5 and 25.5 percent, traders said.
Vols drifted back a bit ahead of the long weekend, but the nearbys were still one to two points firmer on the week.
At-the-money (ATM) implied volatility for June was bid at 21.0-23.0 percent, July at 20.0-20.5 percent and fourth quarter at 15.5-16.5 percent.
Aluminium volatility sank, however, mainly under pressure from granting, said to be by the same Korean player.
"To finance the purchase of nearby call options, they sold forward aluminium options," one trader said.
LME data showed turnover on Wednesday of 1,920 lots of $1,675 calls for January-March 1998 and 3,630 lots of $1,650 calls for the same dates.
The market was already saturated with aluminium options and the heavy granting hammered implied volatility to historic lows, traders said.
ATM volatility on Friday was bid for June at 13.5-14.5 percent and for July at 15.0-15.5 percent, down about two points.
One trader said nearby volatility was the lowest since October 1993, when volatility on the front month was quoted at 11.0/13.0 percent.
"It is getting so low I am telling my customers they are a good buy at these levels. There is not much downside," he said.
Nickel also saw weaker vols as the market saw granting of June to August material in both calls and puts.
"There was some granting but nobody wants them," one dealer said.
June was bid at 20.0-22.0 percent and July at 21.0-22.5 percent, down two to three points.
